description: This board game for adult on a hen do or in another party or good natured fun setting. Each player takes a coloured playing piece and works their way around the board's main track (red) and sub-tracks (childhood, adolescence, middle age and old age) until you reach the twilight zone. First to finish with a hand of 20 scores wins. Wicked cards have scenarios and give a score (which you collect) and Willie cards have scenarios and move you back/forth so many squares or to a set place on the board. Humour is integral to the game both on the board and the cards. Instructions are on the bottom of the box.

A 3D boat and 2-piece water wave are assembled, and 16 pirate penguins are divided according to the number of players. The object is to balance your pirate penguins on the boat without making it tip. Players take it in turns to place their penguins standing up on the boat, wherever they wish. As soon as the boat rocks and one or more penguins fall over the game, or round, ends. The last player before the player who rocked the boat is the winner.

Recommended ages: 5-15 years

DragonClash is a game of strategic combat between mighty dragons of legend and is set in a war-torn, modern-day world. After centuries of abuse from mankind, the dying spirit of Earth has called out to the dragons with hopes they’d help better humanity and reshape the world in elemental harmony. However, the destruction and violence that gave rise to their birth also tainted the dragons, driving them mad with a lust for war. Now the dragons not only battle humanity, but themselves. Ruthlessly hunting for the dragon eggs to satiate their endless hunger for power, the dragons wage an eternal struggle for dominance and the very soul of Earth.

In DragonClash, you are the dragon, hatching your beast from a variety of decks geared towards a specific breed and play style. The core set of DragonClash includes the Red Breather, Blue Adept, Silver Channeler, and Brown Mauler decks. Each deck of 72-cards includes a dragon and a variety of attacks unique to that deck’s theme.

To claim victory, your dragon must win the opponent’s Dragon Egg Card. You can do this by either forcing your opponent to discard his Dragon Egg or by consuming your opponent’s hoard with a Feast card, while a Dragon Egg is hidden there. Players take turns feeding their dragon’s hoard, aging from hatchling to elder wyrm, training a variety of attacks, and engaging in combat. Executing attacks, playing effects, and taking damage depletes your dragon’s Essence (the playing deck) and when a player’s dragon has exhausted all of their Essence, they must flee and lose the game.

Aim of the game: The prince has been turned into a frog. Can you return him to his natural state by collecting kisses and the golden ball, and placing him on the right lily pad?

How it is played:

The central piece of the game is a clear plastic cylinder that has a disk inside. The disk shows the prince on one side, and a frog on the other. It is turned over via a magnetic mechanism: If the cylinder is put on the castle tile, it shows the frog. If it is put on the correct lily pad, the tile is turned over again and the prince reappears.

Players take turn spinning a spinner. The spinner has three different areas: One shows one "kiss" symbol (a pair of lips), the second shows two kisses, and the third one the golden ball. If the spinner points toward one of the kiss symbols, the active player gets the corresponding number of kiss tokens. If it points toward the golden ball, the active player gets the ball token (there is only one ball token, and it constantly changes its owner according to the spinner's results). A player can try rescuing the prince as soon as he/she has collected 3 kisses and the golden ball. To rescue the prince, the cylinder has to be put on the correct lily pad. But only one of the lily pads will make the prince reappear. If the player chooses the wrong lily pad, he/she loses their kiss tokens and has to start collecting new ones. If it is correct and the frog turns into a prince, that player wins the game.

(English)

Hadak útja, or Crossroad of Peoples is a light wargame in the footsteps of the famous Britannia. The game covers the history of the Carpathian Basin from the Roman conquest (12 BC) to the arrival of the Hungarians (907 AD). Players control mighty invading armies - from the glorious Romans and the ferocius Germanic tribes to the dreaded Huns and the peaceful Slavs - that seek to carve a new home on the blood-soaked soil under the Carpathians.

The players move and fight battles with their units in order to occupy and keep given areas. Units include four types of combat units (normal and heavy infantry, normal and heavy cavalry), settlements (oppida and Roman cities) and leaders (e.g. Emperor Trajan, King Attila the Hun or Prince Svatopluk of Moravia). At the end of the turn each people on the map score VPs from their occupied areas.

The game includes a Simple and an Advanced Game. All files will be made available in English as well.

(magyar)

A Hadak útja egy történelmi társasjáték, amely a híres Britannia címÅ± játék nyomdokain a Kárpát-medence küzdelmes múltját mutatja be a római hódítástól (Kr. e. 12.) a magyar honfoglalásig (Kr. u. 907). A játékosok azokat a hódító népeket irányítják - a dicsÅ‘ rómaiaktól és a vad germánoktól a rettegett hunokig és a békés szlávokig -, akik új hazát kerestek a Kárpátok övezte véráztatta síkon.

A játékosok célja, hogy egységeikkel mozogva és csatázva bizonyos területeket foglaljanak el és tartsanak meg. A játékban négyféle harci egység (normál- és nehézgyalogos, normál- és nehézlovas), települések (oppidumok és római városok), illetve vezérek (pl. Traianus császár, Attila hun király vagy Szvatopluk morva fejedelem) kapott helyet. A térképen levÅ‘ népek a fordulók végén pontokat kapnak az általuk elfoglalt területek után.

A játéknak egy KezdÅ‘ és egy Haladó változata is van. Minden szükséges kellék letölthetÅ‘ (lesz) innen.

A children's game themed on Jonathan Swifts "Gulliver's Travels", specifically on Gulliver's encounter with the Lilliputians.

Each player is head of a Lilliputian family clan, consisting of four members. The aim of the game is to tie down the sleeping Gulliver while gaining as few points as possible. Players take turns taking one of the Lilliputian figures, each of which has either a number from 0 to 5 or a rope symbol on its base (not visible when players choose which figure to take). The active player announces the figure's value and decides if they want to put it on their own family card or return it. If a rope symbol is drawn, the player must exchange two of their family members (they may choose to exchange for a member of a different family clan), announce the new values and tie Gulliver down on one arm or leg. A Lilliputian with a rope symbol is worth ten points.
The game ends when Gulliver has been tied down in all four places. The player whose family clan has the lowest total value (all family members added together) wins the game.

A communicative card game in which quotations from the bible have to be put in relation to other texts. The idea behind the game is to show that the bible is still relevant today, to personal life as well as to society and politics.

The game consists of two different sets of cards. One contains quotations from the bible, the other descriptions and aspects of modern life in the form of short texts, messages, promotional slogans etc.

The players have to connect the quotations from the bible on the cards in their hands with the cards from the second set. This doesn't necessarily have to be a literal connection, it involves interpretation and translation into different contexts. 
Each player has a hand of five cards with a quotation from the bible, of which he/she has to choose one to go with the current card from the second set of cards. Each player then has one minute to explain why they have chosen a particular quotation, with the aim of "selling" their choice to the other players. The players then vote on the "best" (i.e. most fitting) quotation. Each round, a different player is the "buyer". He/she uses a set of blue chips numbered 1-5 to secretly vote which quotation they consider best, second best etc. The other players use white chips (also numbered 1-5) to guess the buyer's preferences. Players get points for choosing good (i.e. rated highly by the buyer) quotations as well as for guessing the buyer's preferences. 
The game ends either after a certain number of rounds, or after a player has reached a certain number of points. The player with the most points wins.

Ars Victor is a fast-paced, tense, two-player boardgame of tactical combat. You command a furious fighting force OF THE FUTURE against a ferocious foe. Recruit your armies. Scout out a unique map. Draw a hand of Command Cards. Deploy your Vanguard. The battle is joined!

To win, you must reduce your enemy’s Glory to zero before they do the same to you. Your successes on the battlefield chip away at your enemy’s Glory. It never goes up, only down; so it’s always a tense, back-and-forth race to the bottom.

Your turn is simple: play a Command Card to activate one or more of your units. Move them across the battlefield, and try to slaughter the enemy. In the process, try to hold on to the three Capture Points in the middle of the board, and keep your Headquarters alive.

Combat is resolved in a single roll of multiple colored dice. Dice quantity and color can be affected by terrain, as well as unit Special Abilities. Simple icons on the dice show the results.

The game is based around 96 Wacky cards - each with a wacky thing to do, a point value 1-12 and some with either 'Always' or 'Whenever' written on. There are also 4 prop cards and 4 props - funny glasses, a feather boa, an echo microphone and an elephant nose - with detailed instruction on what to do if you have one of these cards.

The 4 youngest players randomly pick a prop card then take that prop. Wacky cards are shuffled and placed facedown within reach of all. On your turn take a Wacky card, place it face up in front of you and read it aloud to all players. You then do the wacky thing - and if it's marked as an Always card you repeat it every turn; if it's marked as a Whenever card it will be whenever someone else does a particular thing.

The object is to be the player who gets the most points for doing wacky things over an agreed number of rounds. Add up the points on each player's cards - highest points wins.

Carcassone-like tile-laying game for two players.

Two players try to create a recreation park together. The finished park consists of all 36 tiles in a 6x6 square. There are water and land ways on the tiles (including bridges). Some tiles show black or white ducks.

Each player has a different goal: The "land" player tries to build a land way connecting all 4 edges of the park without building any islands and placing two black ducks next to each other. The "water" player tries the same with water ways (and avoiding lakes and placing two white ducks next to each other).

Like in "Carcassonne", on each turn a player draws a tile and places it next to an already played tile. At the end, there must be a 6x6 square. The players receive -1 point for not fulfilling parts of their goal (connecting edges, avoiding islands/lakes, placing black/white ducks together).

Note: The self published version features 36 cards, the Amigo version of Wege and The Legend of Landlock feature 40 tiles.

Bill Johnson – You Wake Up To Marmageddon!

Set in the world of 'Bill Johnson - Zombie Issues Specialist' an e-book by Jon Brown, Marmageddon is a tile-placement game in which Players draw and place tiles, exploring a warehouse - trying to collect the most Marmite.

The tiles feature Marmite, Zombies and movement icons. They must be placed adjacent to tiles that have already been played, in such a way that a warehouse is formed. Having placed a tile, the Player moves his character around the warehouse (based on the movement icons on the tiles), collecting the precious Marmite and defeating the Zombies. Players must escape the warehouse with their collected Marmite before the tiles are exhausted or the warehouse is complete, else suffer the consequences!

Helvetia was created not only from diplomatic relations, but also out of war. There is no longer bloodshed amongst the people of Helvetia, though, as they now prefer to express their rivalry another way. They do it by way of a new sport: the Helvetia Cup.

HELVETIA Cup is a game of simulation football that blends tactical skill, strategy and luck and is set in a fantasy world, with each player acting as a coach in epic games and titanic championships. HELVETIA Cup has both a family version and a geek version.

Short rules description
- In Helvetia Cup two fantasy teams compete against each other
- You play the coach of a soccer team composed of 9 players. For each game you choose 1 goalkeeper, 4 players and 2 substitutes.
- Each player is defined by its abilities, as for example dribble, shoot, tackling, pressure, clearance
Each turn you can move all your players. One hexagon movement is free, if you want to move more you need to spend boost. If a player has no more boost then all its abilities are divided by two.
- After the movement, if the defender has a player in the same hex as the ball, he could try some actions; For example, to steal the ball or tackle. If the offense still has the ball, he can try to shoot or pass.

Spell Thief is a modular Dexterity game for 1-3 Players

Using the room and hallway tiles you build a floor of the Academy on which to attempt your great heist. You must carefully navigate the floor (by flicking your token) avoiding wizard guards and areas of light while sticking to shadows and stealing magic tomes. If you alert the guards you will have to deal with the mighty Iron Sentries that stalk your every move and the awesome power of the Hunters who cast Ice Walls, Snares and Light Traps to try and capture you! If you are brave enough to challenge the upper floors of the tower you might also have to be wary of the fearsome Matron of the Academy.

Codigo Cube is the play anywhere, anytime trivia game using QR Codes and the camera on your Smartphone. QR codes are those little pixilated squares you see everywhere. When you scan them they take you to a website. How Codigo Cube works is there is a QR Code embedded die. Each side of the die contains a different QR Code. Each QR Code represents a different trivia category. First person to get one question correct from all six sides wins!

Mr. Buckethead gets to choose between visiting the candy store or the toy store; somehow, this eventually leads him to prehistoric jungles and the dangerous surface of the moon.

This is an interactive gamebook where the player constantly chooses options in an evolving comic-book-like story, collecting money, items, friends and Action Points (used to activate special powers). The book includes a scoresheet and many puzzles and mini-games throughout, as the player works to gain the challenging Victory Point (by defeating the Moon Monster). Like other books in the series, there is also a 2-player monster fight mini-game included.

ABOUT THE SERIES:
Based on the live action television and film character, this new series of interactive gamebooks is adventure-packed! 64 pages of intense gameplay action with an innovative story structure that allows continuous play across multiple issues. Each issue in this series contains a solo adventure plus a bonus multi-player monster fighting game! The appeal of an evolving RPG with the look and feel of a comic book, the Mr. Buckethead Adventure Game Series is challenging and entertaining fun for all ages!

Another game by the company that specialised in making designs so that partially or totally colour blind people can play. They mainly made traditional games but this is an original game by the company owner.

The game is played on a 7 x 7 grid. Each player must try to get four pegs in a row, hence the name of the game. It is a refined version of Go-Moku or 5-in-a-Row. The limit on placing pegs is that each peg played must be adjacent to an opposition peg. First to get four in a row, wins.

2212: Ginkgo Biloba, the oldest and strongest tree in the world, has become the symbol of a new method for building cities in symbiosis with nature. Humans have exhausted the resources that the Earth offered them, and humanity must now develop cities that maintain a delicate balance between resource production and consumption. Habitable space is scarce, however, and mankind must now face the challenge of building ever upwards. To develop this new type of city, you will gather a team of experts around you, and try to become the best urban planner for Ginkgopolis.

In  Ginkgopolis, the city tiles come in three colors: yellow, which provides victory points; red, which provides resources; and blue, which provides new city tiles. Some tiles start in play, and they're surrounded by letter markers that show where new tiles can be placed.

Begin with three Character cards which grant you starting resources and bonuses to power your game actions. On a turn, each player chooses a Construction or Urbanization card from his hand simultaneously. Players reveal these cards, adding new tiles to the border of the city in the appropriate location or placing tiles on top of existing tiles. Each card in your hand that you don't play is passed on to your left-hand neighbor, so keep in mind how your play might set up theirs!

When you build over a tile, you add its “power" card to your tableau, which provides you additional abilities during the game, allowing you to scale up your building and point-scoring efforts.

A card game that teaches children about some typical tasks police officers have to do and what equipment they need.

Whether the finale of an important soccer tournament or a state visit is taking place, whether there is a case of suspected arson or a suspicious suitcase is found - the police has to face many different challenges. What is to be done in each case and what means are needed is described on the challenge boards. The cards also show different resources that help the police to complete these tasks, such as handcuffs, a walkie-talkie, a police dog, a police horse, helicopter, motorbike etc. Players try to collect all the necessary resources for one of the three current challenges. If they are successful, they earn that challenge card and the points written on the card. The game ends when one player has collected 10 points or when the last card has been drawn. The player with the most points wins the game.

Components: 16 challenge boards, 53 cards, rules

An action game for children aged 4 an up. Players must flick plastic flies into a large plastic frog (with an gaping mouth) while the frog rotates under battery power. While a fly is in flight the other players can attempt to close the frog's mouth by activating their pump.

The object of the game is to be the first to fill one's tiara with all five of the gems.  There are four boards, one for each player.  The player spins the spinner and if it lands on a space with a gem that she (it's mostly a little girls' game) doesn't have in her tiara, she gets it.  There is a "lose a gem space" as well as a "spin again" space (although it has little effect on the game).

Components:
4 Game Boards
20 Gem pieces
Spinner
Instructions

Rancheros is a casual strategy game for 2-4 players in which players take on the role of Mexican Ranchers that are trying to raise various animals to meet the demands of their local meat market. The player will acquire varying amounts of pesos for how they raise their animals while balancing the demands of the meat market. The player with the most pesos when the game ends is the winner.

From the publisher:

Fling your frogs onto the Lily Pad levels to score points. But, beware…someone else’s flung frog may push yours off and leave you scoreless! Challenge friends to a game, or play by yourself to top your best scores. The Lily Pad also acts as a convenient storage and travel case.

Contents: Lily Pad with 5 Levels, 12 Frogs (3 of Each Color), Rules. The lily pad also doubles as a convenient storage case.

This is one of the Patch Products Big Little Games series, designed to be travel games.

From the publisher:
Practice shooting hoops and gain mad skills! Just place the ball on the shooter, press down on the back lever, and your ball flies through the air! Simply aim the shooter where you think you will have a good chance to get the ball into the net, and press down. Includes rules for three games - Horse, Around the World and 3-Point Shootout - so you can challenge friends to different games.

Contents: Basketball hoop with fold-down backboard, attachable basketball shooter, 3 tiny basketballs, rules. The shooter attaches to the hoop for storage. The game takes a few minutes to assemble.

In Foothold Enterprises, you are a young entrepreneur trying to get your startup company going. You have a limited amount of time to see a return on your investments. Buy advertising, win over clients, and put your company on the map!

This solitaire game uses a single deck of custom cards and can be played while standing in line.  It is mechanically inspired by such brilliant push-your-luck games as Zed Deck and Lord of the Rings: The Adventure Deck Game.  Each turn, you flip the top card of the deck and select one of the three aspects of the card on which to bid: advertising, money, or clients.  You then bid as little or as much money as you like.

The card then tells you how many cards to reveal from the top of the deck for the game's counter bid.  You add up the money scores from those revealed cards.  If you bid higher, you win the flipped card!  All revealed cards are placed face-up on the bottom of the deck.  The flipped card is also place face-up, but may be turned sideways to expose the advertising ability if you won the card, or turned upside-down to indicate that you won the clients.

Advertisements give you abilities that allow you to win certain kinds of bids more easily or otherwise manipulate the game rules.  Clients count as Victory Points at the end of the game.  You only gain $2 at the beginning of each turn, so keep an eye on your cash flow, or you'll lose out on important clients or key advertising abilities!

When you have gone through the entire deck (all cards are face-up), simply count up the client values of all the upside-down cards.  This is your score for the game.  Then try to beat that score next game!

Designed for the 2012 Solitaire Print and Play Contest.

A quick 2-card gambling game.

The game is played with a standard deck of cards (without Jokers), divided into two deck -- one red and one black.

Each turn starts with a one coin ante, then each player is dealt one card from each deck, so that each player has one red and one black card.

Simultaneously each player reveals one card -- either red or black.  Then the player with the lowest card showing decides either to drop out or to force a showdown. Since it goes from lowest to highest, not every player will have the opportunity to drop out before the showdown occurs.

When the showdown occurs, everyone shows both of their cards.  The player with the highest black card wins.  Everyone else (except for those who dropped out) then pay the winning player a number of coins equal to the value of the red card (aces are worth 1 coin, and face cards are worth 10 coins). The winner also gets the antes.  If there is no showdown, the surviving player gets the antes.

This game is part of the Cheapass Games Poker Suite that was released on the Cheapass website.

Chaos & Alchemy is a fast-paced game of laboratory building and rivalry between alchemists. Players conduct an experiment each turn by rolling 3 dice, hoping for each die to be at least as high as the shared Fortune Die. Each success lets the alchemist draw a new card from the deck or play a card from hand; each failure means a discard.

Cards represent Innovations to improve the alchemist's laboratory, Misfortunes to make rivals' lives harder, Actions to immediately impact the game, and Reactions to respond to other alchemists' deeds.

When an alchemist rolls doubles in an experiment, Chaos occurs and fortunes change. The experimenter re-rolls the Fortune Die, making success easier or harder to achieve.

Players race to build up a laboratory sophisticated enough to turn lead into gold. The first player with 10 or more points of Innovations in the laboratory is the victor!

Rule clarification: A standard experiment involves rolling 3 dice (this is unclear in the Second Edition rulebook).

Skystrike is a World War 2 Pacific Theater of Operations Nautical wargame  cited by the designer as very suitable for novices in that genre.

The game is based on the crucial battle for Midway Island on the 4th June 1942. To win, the Japanese player has to sink the United State's aircraft carriers and thus capturing Midway Island. The American player wins by preventing the Japanese taking the island and inflicting more losses on the Japanese forces than his own suffer.

Each player has their own board and the game thus uses a blind/search system. Only when the enemy is found can combat occur. Each turn represents 8 hours, so three turns per day are the limit. The searching rule owes a debt to dear old Battleships and the board is overlaid with squares so that movement is by square to square.

Once combat starts, results are determined by a die roll. I think there could be very quick combat rounds "Roll a 6 and the enemy carrier is sunk", that sort of thing (it is intended for beginners after all). When it comes to invading the island, the Japanese player gets only one attempt per game so the player must be pretty sure he has timed it correctly.

There are variants - a quick game and an advanced game, plus rules for designating your aircraft as fighters and/or bombers.

Librium is a unique game for two or more people from ages 14 to 100!

The game consists of a method of placing ‘construction’ cards on to a pivotable base that is either mounted on a tripod, a magnetic base or hung from a ‘hanger wire’ as in the 'Black’ version.

The object of the game is to add the cards to each other in turn without collapsing the structure. No two games are the same and many large structures can be achieved with strategy, nerve and balance, but... the game will ultimately end in chaos!

Four models are available:

The original Family game with attitude!
LIBRIUM Red
For those wanting the challenge of a 30 card game where stability allows for more complex structures... This is the game for you!
Start easy with the Fulcrum card clamped, then when you think you have mastered the dark art of LIBRIUM, unclamp the Fulcrum card and allow it to turn.
But that’s not all...!
Try tilting the Fulcrum card when it can turn freely and ‘hey-presto’, another level of ‘Balance & Chaos’!

Contents:


    30 building cards
    LIBRIUM Tripod (with extendable legs)
    Fulcrum card
    Top Ten Tip card
    Card Storage Box
    Instructions.


Party the night away with
LIBRIUM Blue... The Pocket Pack of laughter!

Just when your friends thought they were going to have to endure another boring night out talking about old times, you slap the pocket sized Lite+ game down on the table and challenge the lot of them!
(It’s hoped by now you have had at least a small bit of practice before you show them the art of LIBRIUM!)

We are not advocating that you should use the Blue as a drinking game, but... The Mag Mount does look particularly magnificent attached to the top of a beer or other drinks bottle!
(For a more sedate game or when younger players are present...use a bean tin!)

Contents include:


    LIBRIUM Mag Mount
    Fulcrum card
    20 classic LIBRIUM cards
    Top Ten Tip card
    Instructions


For the Serious Competitor or Closet Balance & Chaos Junkie!
Librium Black...
Just when you thought pub games were getting boring, and the thought of another game of block balancing was becoming too tedious for words, someone somewhere will be getting all the laughs, spills, thrills, balance & chaos having embarked on the dark art of LIBRIUM Black!
After a small amount of assembly you will begin to see how addictive this game version can be!

The virtually unbreakable supplied Pro Clamp has a jaw of 50mm allowing easy fixture to tables, chairs, bars or any other stable structure. The clamp post can also be angled to make the game more central on a table.

Varying degrees of difficulty can be factored into the game with only slight adjustments as detailed in the instructions.
We already have a World Champion... Maybe you will be next!

Pack Contents:


    30 Classic LIBRIUM cards
    Fulcrum card
    Suspension Rod with Tilt Pivot & Hanger Ring
    Free Turn Connector
    Pro2 Clamp
    2 Part Hanger Wire Ass’y
    Top Ten Tip Card
    Instructions


Treat yourself to a... 
Tin ‘O’ LIBRIUM Green!
Guaranteed calorie free, in fact you will probably burn calories playing it!
The classic LIBRIUM cards offer a rich and meaningful form of entertainment.
The cards are a good source of moral fibre, low in fat (they are very thin), and are great as part of a balanced everyday helping of laughter! 
Each Tin ‘O’ LIBRIUM Green comes packed with goodness including:


    LIBRIUM Mag Mount
    20 classic LIBRIUM cards
    1 Fulcrum card
    1 Top Ten Tip Card
    Instructions
    Storage Tin/Base
    Sealing cap
    Pop-able piece of bubble wrap to annoy people with!

Each player has pawn on the game board nad the object is to move it from start to finish.

In his turn player draws a card and chooses between a light, medium or heavy question (or statement) to answer. Then the card is turned over and who answered correctly andvances hi pawn 1 or 2 fields when light or medium question was chosen and as many fields as dice shows if
difficult question was chosen.

Player who reaches at finish first is the winner.

Control-Alt-Hack is a tabletop card game about white hat hacking, based on game mechanics by gaming powerhouse Steve Jackson Games (Munchkin and GURPS).

You and your fellow players work for Hackers, Inc.: a small, elite computer security company of ethical (a.k.a., white hat) hackers who perform security audits and provide consultation services. Their motto? "You Pay Us to Hack You."

Your job is centered around Missions - tasks that require you to apply your hacker skills (and a bit of luck) in order to succeed. Use your Social Engineering and Network Ninja skills to break the Pacific Northwest's power grid, or apply a bit of Hardware Hacking and Software Wizardry to convert your robotic vacuum cleaner into an interactive pet toy...no two jobs are the same. So pick up the dice, and get hacking!

Reimplements:

    Ninja Burger: Secret Ninja Death Touch Edition

This vintage dexterity game features two foam rubber volleyball athletes inside a vertical playing surface. Each player controls a "flipper" dial that moves his athlete under a plaxiglass shield. The volleyball is a plastic disc that is tossed back-and-forth under the plexiglass.

The athletes are manipulated to catch or instantly return the white disc representing the ball. A dropped volleyball or a return that lands out of bounds scores a point for the other player. First player to five points is declared the winner.

Includes the plastic volleyball court assembly, two plastic legs, and two discs.

In Bohn To Be Wild!, a standalone title that celebrates fifteen years of the classic Bohnanza card game, players want to do what they've always done: Plant beans in their fields and sell them for as many coins as possible, while trading cards with other players to get around the restriction of not being able to rearrange cards in your hand.

Bohn To Be Wild! mixes things up, however, by including eleven new types of beans – including Jamaica, helmet and horse beans – rules for solo play, and special "wild" beans. Unlike the original German Bohnanza, this game allows for play with up to seven players.

In a post-apocalyptic world, a few months ago a zombie outbreak took charge of the largest cities on the planet. Urban areas are infested and the military are planning some reconnaissance missions on the major affected areas.

You and your team of soldiers were in one of those missions, flying a town overrun by zombies. But suddenly the unexpected happened! A problem with the helicopter engine causes the loss of altitude and the aircraft is going down. Luckily, (or not), you and the other members survived the crash.

It looks like the survivors crashed over some abandoned and unknown building. The problem is that, just like the whole city, there are zombies everywhere!

With low ammo, the only way to survive is to cross the interior of the building and search for exit.

This is a survival game, where characters are lost in an environment full of zombies.

The map, zombie encounters, weapons and ammo are randomly created and each game is never the same.

It is a print and play game. The PDF includes:
-24 map tiles
-Zombies and soldiers miniatures (cut, fold and glue)
-Modern weapons & ammo counters

From the publisher's and Toy Directory websites:
The board is used on a slight incline and the game pieces are magnetic. The Magical Rainbow is a magnetized game that takes children on a special adventure through 7 magical lands. Players race to a pot of gold, watching out for Paddy the Leprechaun, who on every turn travels from land to land protecting his gold. Throughout the journey players will try to collect gold coins, avoid the Leprechaun and his lucky trinkets, and use strategy to win the game. The first player to reach the pot of gold at the end of the Rainbow wins, however the game encourages sharing with others in need. This game is designed to teach children color recognition, sequencing, patterns, counting, strategy and sharing.

"Using a rainbow game theme lets kids imagine what it would be like living on a Magical Rainbow, and helping Paddy the leprechaun give out his gold to people in need.  The rainbow game combines colors and a magnetic 3d game set that keep kids entertained game after game.  The other goal for Magical Rainbow was to create a board game that could be played with one child.  There are a lot of one child families and what good is a board game if you don’t have anyone to play the game with?  Magical Rainbow can be used as a standalone make believe play set."  The game pieces double as flexible magnetic play pieces that have letters and numbers on the reverse side. They can be used on the front or back of the game board or on any metallic surface to assist children in developing recognition with the alphabet, numbers and words.

Awards: 2009 Family Choice Award, Creative Child Magazine's Game of the Year award, Dr Toy Best Picks, 2010

4 or 6 players to play. Players are split into 2 teams and seated in an alternate fashion. Each team starts with a fixed number of hit points. Cards are played to attack any player of the opposing team and successful attacks result in cards drawn for the attacked player. If the hand limit of cards is surpassed, the hit points will be reduced. The attacking team also gets a crystal and crystals can be exchanged for a cup. A team wins by either collecting 5 cups or decreasing the opposing team's hit points to zero.

The quiz game for the television series on Pro 7.
500 cards are divided into three stacks of three rounds. 
In the first round, players must answer 10 questions marking the correct answers with the electronic pen. Each correct answer takes 4 seconds. Unused time can be used in the second round after answering 12 questions. 
6 questions are in the final round. 
Points for correct answers are added up and the player with the most points wins.

Objective: being a dog: catch all hares: being a hare: escape to field no. 54
 - moving by turns -
depending on no. of players: 1-3 hares & 1-3 dogs; 
1 hares may roll the die twice getting a headstart
2 ending on a red (or marked blue space) hares & dogs must run an additional circuit
3 hares may jump (=shortcut) if they throw a '1' standing on a space with an adjacent black arrow
4 a hare is caught if a dog overtakes or ends on the same space

Shield Breaker is a fantasy skirmish wargame for use with 28mm miniatures. Players alternately active their models, moving, shooting and fighting with them. Winning is partly based on beating up the opposing warband, partly on controling the centre of the board.

The Warband Builder can acccommodate almost any fantasy figures on the market.

Relic is a board game in which two to four players each assume the role of a powerful hero from the Warhammer 40,000 universe and bravely venture forth to shield the Antian Sector from certain doom. By completing missions and defeating enemies, characters compete to gain rewards and experience, furthering their chance of being the first to defeat whatever evil lies beyond the Warp rift.

Building on the foundations of the Talisman system, Relic is an adventure game in which seemingly straightforward choices mask scores of possibilities. For those who haven't played the classic fantasy adventure game Talisman, this means that on each turn, a player rolls a single six-sided die before moving his playing piece that number of spaces clockwise or counter-clockwise around the region (outer, middle, or inner) of the board it currently occupies. That player then draws a card or cards to see what he's encountered, pitting his heroic persona against foul enemies, dangerous locations, and fantastic strangers. And all the while, these intrepid heroes rise in power, as they work their way toward the ultimate goal at the center of the board.

—description from the publisher

Objective: be the first catching all enemies or capture their headquarter
 - moving by turns -
2 players (or groups - red Indians & cowboys) try to catch each other by rolling the die; a '6' can't be used - except on marked (crossed) spaces 
remarks:
published during late 1950's

Exact Change
Best Game on the market to teach children to count money!

Teach children to count money with a fun game the entire family can enjoy!

Exact Change combines an excellent teaching lesson with fun, fast paced action that the entire family will love. The goal is to play all of your cards first. You can discard cards by matching the color of the last card played, by matching the currency value (play a penny on a penny), or by making EXACT CHANGE. Making exact change allows you to discard multiple cards that add up to the value of the last card played. If the last card played shows a quarter, you can make exact change by playing two dimes and a nickel- allowing you to discard three cards in one play!
If you’re looking for games about money! Look no further! Exact Change is the best game on the market that teaches children to count money!  Exact Change is a favorite of teachers!

Winner of iParenting Media, Dr. Toy’s Top 100, Creative Child Magazines Seal of Excellence, and the National Parenting Center’s Seal of Approval awards!

Winner of a 2013 KIDS PRODUCT OF THE YEAR AWARD & a 2013 PREFERRED CHOICE AWARD in the Educational Products & Cards Games for Kids categories!

In this game children try to place their raindrops, consisting of three parts, on the board. The die decides which action a player has to take. The first player to have no raindrop pieces left wins the game.

At the beginning of the game, each player gets three wooden raindrop pieces - one small disk and two rings. The larger ring fits around the smaller one, which in turn fits around the small disk. Players take turns rolling the die. The die determines whether the player is allowed to put a piece of his/her raindrop on the board (rain symbol), loses a turn (cloud symbol), has to take back a drop (sun symbol) or is allowed to place the rainbow, thus locking a field on the board. The game ends when one player has placed all his/her raindrop parts on the board.

The pirates have found out that huge golden orbs can be found on the large Caribbean island, and of course they are trying to get them. Each player has a pirate ship and tries to bring a golden orb to his/her home harbour. On their way, the pirates have to avoid other pirates because they will naturally try to steal their golden orb. But even the best pirate has to strike the sails when the weather is bad. A magnetic spinner in the center of the board rotates the golden orbs around and also causes the dreaded storms. This causes surprising twists of fate in the race for the golden orbs.

Game takes place on a 9 x 10 grid of circles; furthest row on either player's side of the board features circles filled with letters "C-H-A-C-H-A-C-H-A" and covered with game's checker pieces that have corresponding letters on top, each player having chosen a different side and color.  Players take turns placing three shoe pieces of their own color on the board, which will not move during the game and will help or hinder the players depending on ownership.

Players then take turns moving lettered pieces, one at a time but with each piece needing to move five times (as the player says "Cha" with each step,) to get to a corresponding letter on the opposite side.  Pieces can move in any direction except diagonal and can jump, but do not capture or eliminate others.  First player to find a home for all their pieces on their opponent's side wins.

Note:  the game does not have a publication date.  However, it features both "Hassenfeld Bros." and "Hasbro" names listed as publisher, and the "cha-cha-cha" was first known at some point in the 1950's or 1960's.

From the publisher:
"Barnyard Stampede is a fast and furious racing card game where farm animals compete to see who can race to the barn first. Set the barn box in the center of the table. Each player chooses an animal and flips a card face up on the start line. The rest of the cards are then dealt out to each player face down. Ready, Set, MOOO-VE IT! Players flip cards over from their hand one at a time searching for a card that matches their animal. If a match is made, you play the card in front of the start line – taking a step towards the barn. The first to tag the barn wins the race! Excellent game for young children!"

A magnetic game for children with a die from 1 to 3.

The dwarfs are lucky! Gold can be found on the road. Huge golden coins are just waiting to be collected. If luck is on your side, you can even carry home a whole stack of coins...unless one of the other players takes them away first!

Gameplay: Players take turns rolling the die. They then move their dwarf pawn the corresponding number of spaces on the circular track. If they land on a gold coin (a wooden disc is placed on every third space during set-up), the dwarf is put on the coin, which sticks to the dwarf's base magnetically. On the next turn, the dwarf moves on with the coin attached. He tries to reach home (every dwarf has his home section in one corner of the board), continuing to collect more coins if possible. If one dwarf lands on a space occupied by another dwarf, the newcomer steals the other's gold and sends him home. The game ends when all coins have been brought home. The player who collected the most coins wins the game.

Advertising game to Bavaria and the Bavarian Radio broadcasts. In his turn players rolls, moves and follows the instructions of the achieved event fields like answering trivia questions. Who first reaches the goal box first is the winner, but needs to say "Long live the king", or else he must return behind the last player.

From the rules:

The object of the game is to gain all the letters spelling LIBATION.  The first one to do so (or last one under the table) is declared the winner.

Game-play

Players take turns rolling the die and moving around the game board.  Players perform various actions when landing on a space (chug-a-lug-active player drinks, boomba-la-roomba-everyone drinks, chance-active player draws a card and performs *that* action).  Players also collect a letter of the word "libation" corresponding to the space landed on.  The corner squares are similar to monopoly (start, dungeon, throne room, go to dungeon).  Gameplay continues until one player successfully completes the word libation or until all other players are 'under the table'.

Objective: be the first entering opposing port with your battleship or sink enemy battleship
- acting/moving by turns -
each player gets 1 d6 and an additional die as route indicator, 6 mines, 12 small & 1 battleship;
dice: 'a 4 combined with NO' = 4 transverse moves direction NO
 - protect your battleship with your small ships, place mines and try to surprise your opponent; moving upon or across an enemy ship is going to sink it.
remarks:
published 1930's
